Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\), where L is a linear operator. We investigate the effects of applying a Fourier transform, denoted as \\(\\hat{u}(k, t) = \\mathcal{F}(u(x, t))\\), on this system.

If a Fourier transform \\(\\hat{u}(k, 0) = \\mathcal{F}(u(x, 0))\\) is applied to the initial condition \\(u(x, 0)\\) and then the system evolves according to \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\) without further intervention, will \\(\\hat{u}(k, T)\\) at time T be the same as if the initial condition was directly evolved in the transformed domain under \\(\\frac{\\partial \\hat{u}}{\\partial t} = \\mathcal{F}(Lu)\\)?
Explanation: The evolution of \\(u(x, t)\\) under \\(L\\) followed by a Fourier transform is equivalent to evolving \\(\\hat{u}(k, 0)\\) under the transformed operator \\(\\mathcal{F}(L)\\). The commutativity of the Fourier transform with linear differential operators ensures that transforming first and then evolving gives the same result as evolving first and then transforming.
